w:r.w:t: Gap here—connect the former sentence better, as what you are saying in the former sentence is not very clear. What is the significance of the title, and what exactly is “quite so clear” about it? Isn’t it actually confusing because it means both “goddess and “prostitute”?
Is this the prostitute?
Missing antecedent—who is this “he”? “the worker”?

This intro could be clearer. Are you going to be talking about the prostitute or the boss figure? You seem like you set it up as the prostitute, then suddenly switch to the boss. But then you begin the next paragraph with the prostitute, which is confusing.
Just put this in parentheses later
Interesting info
What does this mean exactly? That they are not modern at all? What do they sell?
Why would they be stronger consumers if they belong to a lower class and do not have money? What is this based on?
This needs more visual evidence.

What kind of consumerism is gambling? It seems to be different from just purchasing expensive goods like the kind you describe earlier with the department stores. What does gambling gain anyway, and who benefits from it?
Interesting detail here. Expand.
This is too many ideas compounded too quickly without evidence.

The question that comes to mind here is: is the experience of modernity the same for men and women, then, as you seem to point to, or are there some differences? Can the woman be more of a producer (via prostitution) than the male?
New idea. Stick to one idea per paragraph.
Equal member to the skyline?
What does he say? Remind the reader.
This information comes too quickly. Move it to later.
Idea or ideal?

You tend to read a bit too much into the details without much evidence. These kinds of claims require much more visual evidence. I don’t understnd how the newspaper is a “modern ideal.” You need to explain this part first. Was there something written on the paper that tied it together with consumerist culture?
This is a good point—maybe you could have elaborated on this as his main time to the bourgeois lifestyle instead of gambling. The prostitute becomes the replacement for his own labor.
interesting take on the character
